image.altText: People cross a city street.

items.synopsis: Growing concerns about crime and anti-social behaviour — coupled with media headlines pronouncing a "crime wave" — prompted police to ask for wider powers last month. But are they accurate?

title.children: Is there a crime wave happening in Adelaide's CBD?

image.altText: The captain of the missing boat, Yunardi Ardi, reunites with his family

items.synopsis: Search and rescue crews are continuing to scour the waters off Aceh for the final crew member of the wooden boat that went missing on Sunday night.

title.children: Indonesian boat captain details the last moment he saw missing crew member, as search goes on

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe says Australia's economy has entered the "third phase" in its fight against high inflation. Here's what it means for interest rates and mortgages, and whether more rate rises are likely.

title.children: The RBA says the fight against inflation has reached its 'third phase'. Here's what it means for interest rates

image.altText: Jo O'Halloran wearing a blue top in a portrait.

items.synopsis: Medical scans cost some patients thousands in out-of-pocket expenses, and they are increasingly not covered by bulk-billing. But it's possible to save money by shopping around.

title.children: Patients could be saving hundreds of dollars on medical scans – and it's as simple as shopping around

image.altText: Oyster mushrooms

items.synopsis: Australia's mushroom industry says there's no chance poisonous mushrooms could enter commercial products, as the big supermarkets say fungi sales are still going strong.

title.children: 'Absolutely impossible' for toxic mushrooms to enter Australian supply chain, growers say

image.altText: A soccer team wearing yellow and green hugs each other after scoring a goal

items.synopsis: Find out where you can watch the Matildas in the FIFA Women's World Cup semifinal.

title.children: What time do the Matildas play tonight? Everything you need to know about the semifinal against England

image.altText: A group of women wearing yellow and green uniforms standing in a line jump in the air celebrating

items.synopsis: Australia and England have long-standing rivalries in men's sport, but for tonight's semifinal, how relevant are these old myths to these bright young teams?

title.children: Matildas' World Cup semifinal is not about old rivalries, but new mythmakers

image.altText: A man on his phone in a yard.

items.synopsis: The financial complaints authority appears to have made inconsistent rulings on whether to give customers refunds after phishing scams, based on whether customers admit to clicking dodgy links.

title.children: Roger knew something had gone 'desperately wrong' when he checked his phone and saw 11 new payees on his banking app

image.altText: Matildas fans show support during a 'Send Off Match' between Australia and France

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: PM backs away from Matildas public holiday push. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By political reporter Stephanie Borys Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is backing away from his push for a public holiday if the Matildas win the Women's World Cup. The final decision rests with state and territory leaders, and while some are on board with the idea, others aren't convinced due to the costs on small businesses. Albanese had previously declared the matter would be discussed at today's national cabinet meeting. But speaking on Triple M Hobart, he now says that's not the case. "We won't actually be discussing it today, we are discussing housing and other issues," he says. "It's up to the states and territories what they do. But when the public holiday was held for the memorial day for the Queen, what happened was that a whole range of small businesses went gang busters on that day." Yesterday, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton called the PM's push for a public holiday a "stunt" and an "ego trip" .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM backs down from Matildas public holiday discussions

children.content: By political reporter Stephanie Borys
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is backing away from his push for a public holiday if the Matildas win the Women's World Cup.
The final decision rests with state and territory leaders, and while some are on board with the idea, others aren't convinced due to the costs on small businesses.
Albanese had previously declared the matter would be discussed at today's national cabinet meeting. But speaking on Triple M Hobart, he now says that's not the case.
"We won't actually be discussing it today, we are discussing housing and other issues," he says.

"It's up to the states and territories what they do. But when the public holiday was held for the memorial day for the Queen, what happened was that a whole range of small businesses went gang busters on that day."
Yesterday, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
called the PM's push for a public holiday a "stunt" and an "ego trip"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea has claimed a US soldier who bolted into the North across the Korean border last month did so after being "disillusioned at the inequality of American society". Private 2nd Class Travis King entered North Korea while on a tour of the Joint Security Area (JSA) on the heavily fortified border between the two Koreas, becoming the first American detained in the North in nearly five years. The North's official Korean Central News Agency said King told investigators he had decided to enter North Korea because he "harbored ill feeling against inhuman maltreatment and racial discrimination within the US Army". The Pentagon on Tuesday said it could not verify alleged comments made by King that North Korean state media reported, but that Washington remained focused on his safe return. "The department's priority is to bring Private King home, and that we are working through all available channels to achieve that outcome," a Pentagon spokesperson said. AP/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Korea claims detained US soldier 'disillusioned at the inequality of American society'

props.alt: A photo of Travis King. He is a black man  in his 20s with dark eyes.

children.content: (Reuters: File)
North Korea has claimed a US soldier who bolted into the North across the Korean border last month did so after being "disillusioned at the inequality of American society".
Private 2nd Class Travis King
entered North Korea while on a tour of the Joint Security Area (JSA) on the heavily fortified border between the two Koreas, becoming
the first American detained in the North in nearly five years.

The North's official Korean Central News Agency said King told investigators he had decided to enter North Korea because he "harbored ill feeling against inhuman maltreatment and racial discrimination within the US Army".
The Pentagon on Tuesday said it
could not verify alleged comments
made by King that North Korean state media reported, but that Washington
remained focused on his safe return.
"The department's priority is to bring Private King home, and that we are working through all available channels to achieve that outcome," a Pentagon spokesperson said.
AP/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The national anti-scam centre is warning fraudsters are targeting fans on social media, offering fake ticket sales and fake live-stream links to matches. The consumer watchdog, the ACCC, is reminding consumers to only buy from authorised ticket sellers, and to double-check a streaming site before entering any payment details to watch the game. "We are already seeing initial reports of scam activity, particularly on Facebook, where scammers are responding to posts from people looking for tickets and using compromised accounts to sell non-existent tickets," ACCC deputy chair Catriona Lowe says. "There have also been reports of scammers claiming there is a problem with the payment and asking for it to be made again."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas fans are being urged to be wary of scammers ahead of tonight's game

children.content: The national anti-scam centre is warning fraudsters are targeting fans on social media, offering fake ticket sales and fake live-stream links to matches.
The consumer watchdog, the ACCC, is reminding consumers to
only buy from authorised ticket sellers, and to double-check a streaming site before entering any payment details
to watch the game.

"We are already seeing initial reports of scam activity, particularly on Facebook, where scammers are responding to posts from people looking for tickets and using compromised accounts to sell non-existent tickets," ACCC deputy chair Catriona Lowe says.
"There have also been reports of scammers claiming there is a problem with the payment and asking for it to be made again."

image.altText: Close up shot of Anthony Albanese.

items.synopsis: Boosting housing supply and reforming planning and zoning laws will be high on the agenda when national cabinet meets in Brisbane today, but the Greens are underwhelmed with renting measures that are already in place across most of the country.

image.altText: Amanda Rishworth wearing clear glasses and white blzaer speaking at podium into microphone.

image.altText: A London Metropolitan Police vehicle parked outside the Russian embassy.

items.synopsis: Unlike the rest of the world, the Bureau of Meteorology is still not ready to say an El Niño is underway. But the outlook for spring suggests a dry season ahead, with experts warning of heightened fire risk regardless.

image.altText: Donald Trump stands at a microphone. He is wearing a blue suit and red tie and pictured against a dark background.

image.altText: CLose up of Dorothy Angell smiling

image.altText: The backs of four young Afghan girls facing men perched above them who are Taliban supporters.

image.altText: two cattle walking off a truck and onto a live export ship.

image.altText: Coral reef with small fish

image.altText: Head shot of woman with cane with skull handle resting on her face.

items.synopsis: As Australia prepares to commemorate the 50th anniversary of our withdrawal from Vietnam, actor Kate Mulvany opens up about the toll the war took on her veteran father and her and the unanswered questions about Agent Orange.

title.children: 'I'm proudly disabled': actor Kate Mulvany on a lifetime of pain and the legacy of Vietnam
